g.title: Rectangle
g.text: Bridge (=Handle/body)Separate abstraction and implementation so both can change independently

g.title: Rectangle.45
g.desc: To share implementation across different abstractions
g.text: To share implementation across different abstractions

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: To change implementation (=implementor) of an object during r...
g.text: To change implementation (=implementor) of an object during runtime

g.title: Folded Corner.54
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern is often applied to introduce layer...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern is often applied to introduce layering with a software system. The separation of high level logic from low level logic, abstraction from implementation, introduces reusability, readability and testability, because code is ‘logically’ divided.

g.title: Folded Corner.57
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern entails both the positive and negat...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern entails both the positive and negative side of the Single Responsibility principle. The pattern prescribes to separate the implementation details from the abstraction. This introduces an extra form of indirection as opposed to having the implementation directly within the abstraction. The additional form of indirection causes the readability, navigability and debuggability of the code to decrease, because logic is more scattered.

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern compliments the Single Responsibili...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern compliments the Single Responsibility principle by introducing layering in our system so both Abstractions and Implementors can evolve independently. This ensures readability, reusability, testability and stability. All aspects are compared against an implementation where Implementor logic is situated within the Abstraction directly. Variation is achieved via inheritance. Readability, because the code can be read from an abstract point of view prior to diving into the details. This allows ‘navigation ease’ rather than being overwhelmed by all implementation details directly. Reusability, because multiple abstractions could re-use the same implementation. In contrast, situating the implementation directly within the Abstraction would result in duplication where the same Implementor logic is required across different Abstractions. Inheritance is used to minimize duplication, but when having intertwined inheritance hierarchies it will result in a ‘class explosion’ (via inheritance on inheritance). This results in a decrease in readability, navigability and debuggability. The Bridge design pattern overcomes this negative side affect. Testability, because we can test the Abstraction and Implementor in isolation. This results shrinkage of the ‘problem’ window, which allows finding issues quicker and bringing code faster under test. Stability, changing the Abstraction cannot directly impact the Implementor and vice versa. This reduces the chance of breaking logic unrelated to the change. As an addition to the stability aspect, the clients of the Abstraction have less knowledge on the implementation details. This might result in less re-compilation and redeploying of client code.

g.title: Folded Corner.75
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern separates an intertwined inheritanc...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern separates an intertwined inheritance hierarchy into separate, parallel inheritance hierarchies. An intertwined inheritance hierarchy is a hierarchy with two or more dimensions (e.g. color and shape). The problem with an intertwined inheritance hierarchy is that it results in code duplication. This is because variation is solved on the class level, while it should be solved on the object level. The Bridge design pattern separates intertwined inheritance hierarchy by using composition between them. Using this approach, the code sharing is resolved on the object level.

g.title: Folded Corner.86
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern ensures separation between implemen...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern ensures separation between implementation and abstraction. This can ensure binary compatibility, which reduces re-compilation of client-code dependent on the abstraction. The pImpl (pointer to implementation) idiom in C++ is a language specific implementation of the Bridge pattern that ensures binary compatibility. E.g. in C++ libraries could be ‘packaged’ in the form of a DLL (Dynamic Linked Library). A change in the header, serving as an interface towards the client, of such a DLL could result in binary incompatibility. E.g. when we change or add a private member, the size of the object changes and thus re-compilation is required. The Bridge pattern reduces the re-compilation time, which can be especially beneficial in large software systems.

g.title: Rectangle.91
g.desc: The amount of subclasses grows ‘explosively’ for relative sim...
g.text: The amount of subclasses grows ‘explosively’ for relative simple changes

g.title: Folded Corner.93
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern can prevent a ‘class explosion’ for...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern can prevent a ‘class explosion’ for relative small changes within an inheritance hierarchy. A small variation of the hierarchy requires us to introduce a lot of new sub-classes. This is often an indication of an intertwined inheritance hierarchy that needs to be sub divided into parallel inheritance hierarchies. An intertwined inheritance hierarchy, that is a hierarchy that contains multiple dimensions, can result in exponential class growth. Exponential class growth is caused by introducing more dimensions, not more variants. However, more variants still causes ‘rapid’ class growth in an intertwined inheritance hierarchy, only not exponential. The separation of these hierarchies, by using the Bridge pattern, ensures independent growth and reusability. Subclasses from the abstract hierarchy can benefit from the same sub classes of the implementation hierarchy. The bridge pattern ‘shifts’ a increase in class construction to an increase in object construction.

g.title: Folded Corner.115
g.desc: The Bridge design pattern allows objects (=Abstractions) to c...

g.text: The Bridge design pattern allows objects (=Abstractions) to change implementation (=Implementor) during runtime. This flexibility might be useful in case the object requests different behavior based on certain conditions. The pattern enables this behavior via Polymorphism and separation of concern. The so called Implementor, that represents the implementation, is defined in a separate class. The Implementor follows the Implementor interface. The Abstraction uses the implementor interface and is capable to change its behavior completely by assigning a single member variable. The runtime behavior switch might be arranged externally by the client (via injection) or internally in the Abstraction.
